awd_titl_txt: An Entropy Approach to Invariance and Reachability of Uncertain Control Systems with Limited Information
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will investigate the control of uncertain nonlinear systems with limited information and with respect to reachability (i.e., the ability to eventually reach a desired region) and invariance (i.e., the ability to always remain in a desired region) objectives. Digital components such as communication systems, digital sensors, and microprocessors are being used ubiquitously in modern control systems to implement closed-loop control. Example systems that utilize closed-loop control include traffic network, autonomous transportation, power networks, and assisted living systems. The intricate interactions between the digital and physical components introduces major challenges in the analysis and control of such systems that cannot be addressed by the methods available in classical control theory. For example, due to the finite bandwidth of communication channels between sensors and controllers, information exchange between them is limited. The fundamental question of whether certain control objectives are realizable by taking into account such limited information exchange cannot be answered by classical control theory. The notion of entropy (i.e., a measure of uncertainty in a system’s initial condition) as an information measure has shown to be a key concept in addressing these types of questions. This project will investigate novel notions of entropiesy for invariance and reachability properties for uncertain nonlinear systems. The results of this project will enable the first step towards the efficient deployment of many innovative applications including underwater vehicles, sensor networks, and industrial control networks.

The main goal of this project is the analysis of information measures for nondeterministic control systems to determine the minimal data rates necessary for the realization of invariance and reachability properties. In addition, this project will also analyze minimal data rates for interconnected nondeterministic control subsystems to enforce invariance properties based on data rates of subsystems. Specifically, the project will introduce the notion of subsystem invariance entropy, in which lower and upper bounds for the invariance entropy of the overall interconnected system are computed compositionally. Similar to the analysis of limited information feedback, formal synthesis of controllers for solving certain complex control objectives, taking into account the digital components, is a challenge that cannot be addressed with classical techniques. A relatively recent approach, namely, the abstraction-based controller synthesis method, has proven to be a promising candidate to address this class of problems. This project will use the developed information measures to quantify the computational complexity underling the abstraction-based synthesis approach. Finally, the project will research numerical algorithms using abstraction-based techniques to compute upper bounds of the researched entropy notions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded project has significantly advanced our understanding of control systems, particularly in the realm of minimal data rates required for enforcing control tasks, by leveraging innovative concepts rooted in information theory, control theory, and entropy. These findings are especially relevant for designing efficient and robust control systems in environments where data transmission is constrained, and they are poised to influence the future of control applications in networked and autonomous systems.

A pioneering contribution of this project is in the study of invariance entropy, which measures the smallest average rate of information required to keep a control system within a specified subset of its state space. While invariance entropy has been a topic of interest for both deterministic and uncertain control systems, this project was the first to develop numerical methods for rigorously estimating upper bounds on this quantity. The methods employed are based on set-valued numerical analysis and graph-theoretic constructions, integrating existing algorithms to compute bounds for both linear and nonlinear systems. The accuracy of these numerical estimates was validated through comparisons with theoretical values, showing that they are closely aligned. This breakthrough provides system designers with practical tools for accurately estimating invariance entropy, which is crucial for designing control systems that must operate efficiently under constraints on data transmission.

The project also introduced the concept of reachability entropy, which quantifies the smallest data rate sufficient to enforce a "reach-while-stay" specification. This specification requires that a system reach a target state while remaining within certain constraints, a common requirement in many control applications. The research established a data-rate theorem that identifies reachability entropy as a tight lower bound on the data rates necessary to satisfy these specifications. Additionally, the project developed a numerical procedure for computing an upper bound on reachability entropy for discrete-time control systems, using finite abstractions. 

State estimation in control systems, particularly when information is transmitted over a finite bit rate channel, was another focus of this project. State estimation is a fundamental problem in control theory, involving determining the current state of a system based on limited information. This project delved into understanding the minimal bit rate required to ensure that state estimation errors remain within acceptable bounds. The concept of restoration entropy, which characterizes this minimal bit rate, was central to this investigation. Previous research in this area had established that restoration entropy is a critical measure for determining the bit rate necessary to keep estimation errors within a specified range. However, existing methods for estimating restoration entropy were either computationally complex or impractical for large systems. To address this, the project introduced a modular approach that decomposes large networks into smaller, more manageable subsystems. By solving a distributed optimization problem for each subsystem and then combining the results, the project was able to estimate an upper bound on the restoration entropy for the entire network. This approach not only made the estimation process more feasible for complex systems but also demonstrated its effectiveness through practical examples. The ability to estimate restoration entropy in large networks has important implications for designing efficient control systems, particularly in applications where data transmission is limited.

Another major breakthrough of the project is the exploration of minimal data rates necessary to enforce regular safety properties in uncertain control systems. Traditional control tasks such as set invariance, state estimation, or stabilization have long been studied in the context of minimal data rates, but this project extended the investigation to regular safety properties, marking a novel contribution to the field. Regular safety properties, essential for ensuring that a control system does not exhibit undesirable behaviors, can be modeled using deterministic finite automata (DFA). The project introduced the concept of invariance feedback entropy (IFE) for hybrid systems, which are formed by combining a DFA with a control system. This IFE provides a measure of the minimal data rate required for a coder-controller to enforce these safety properties within the control system. The key finding was that if a hybrid system possesses a nonempty controlled invariant set that satisfies a specific property, it is possible to design a coder-controller with a data rate equal to or greater than the IFE, ensuring the maintenance of the regular safety property. This approach was validated through practical implementation, where a coder-controller was designed to enforce a regular safety property in a linear control system. This research broadens the scope of control tasks that can be addressed with minimal data rates.

In summary, this project has made substantial contributions to the field of control theory by developing new methods for understanding and estimating the minimal data rates required for various control tasks. These advances not only enhance the theoretical understanding of control systems but also offer practical tools for designing more efficient and robust systems, particularly in environments where data transmission is a limiting factor.
